concept.title: The Science of Stain Removal
concept.shortdesc: Stain removal involves breaking down or lifting stains from fabric. Knowing the type of stain and the right cleaning method can make the process easier.

section.title: Types of Stains
section.p: Different types of stains need different treatments:

dlentry.dd: Stains from organic materials ex. blood, sweat, egg. Use cleaners with enzymes.
Greasy stains from butter, oils, makeup, etc. Use soap or detergents to break up the oil.
Plant-based stains ex. coffee, tea, wine. Use a mild acidic cleaner like vinegar.
Pigments that discolor fabics ex. ink, berries. Use special cleaners or bleach to remove.

ul.li: Soap and detergents: Lift dirt and grease.
Enzymes: Break down tough stains like food or sweat.
Bleach: Lightens or removes color stains.
Solvents: Help dissolve sticky or oily stains.
Warm water for food stains to activate enzymes in cleaners.
Hot water is good for greasy stains, but not on delicate fabrics.

section.title: Common Mistakes to Avoid
section.p: Here are some common mistakes and how to avoid them:

ul.li: Using hot water on protein-based stains makes them set in the fabric.
Rubbing stains hard can push them deeper into the fabric.
Using the wrong cleaner for the stain type.
